Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of High Performance Computers for the Molecular Education and Research Consortium in Undergraduate computational chemistRY (MERCURY)
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program, Professor George Shields from Bucknell University and collaborators from a variety of primarily undergraduate institutions that include Maria Gomez (Mount Holyoke), Carol Parish (U of Richmond), George Shields (Hamilton), Marc Zimmer (Connecticut), Maria Nagan (Truman State), Tricia Shepherd (Westminster), Mauricio Cafiero (Rhodes), Kelling Donald (Richmond), Becky Eggimann (Wheaton), Daqing Gao (Central State), Clifford Padgett (Armstrong Atlantic State U), Eric Patterson (Truman State), Adam Van Wynsberghe (Hamilton), Kelly Anderson (Roanoke College), Sudeep Bhattacharyay (U. Wisconsin-Eau Clare), Jim Phillips (U. Wisconsin-Eau Clare), and Aimee Tomlinson (North Georgia College) will acquire a computer cluster with an estimated 8 teraFLOPS of processing power and 14 terabytes of additional disk space. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels, especially in areas such as materials science, biochemistry, clusters, and physical organic chemistry.

Computer systems and clusters of computers are used by chemists and biochemists to investigate reactions and the properties of chemicals and materials using theoretical models and programs. The computer calculations are used, often along with experimental data, to model and better understand many types of complex chemical and biological phenomena. They are also used to predict results and guide experiments. This resource will be used in research and in course work by undergraduate students and faculty at several institutions training them in computational chemistry methodology with a modern computer system. Besides the home institution there will be participation of students and faculty from a Molecular Education and Research Consortium in Undergraduate computational chemistRY commonly denominated as MERCURY.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 17 MERCURY (Molecular Education and Research Consortium in Undergraduate computational chemistRY) faculty all work with undergraduates on research projects that result in excellent science while simultaneously transforming our undergraduate students understanding of science. Overall, during the three years of this grant, the 17 MERCURY investigators published 78 peer-reviewed papers with their undergraduate students and collaborators. The peer-review publication rate is 1.5 papers/faculty/year, which is three times the rate for physical science faculty at undergraduate institutions (Academic Excellence: The Sourcebook, Research Corporation, 2001; see Section 5, page 186).

Overall, during the three year period of this grant, the 17 MERCURY investigators worked with 200 undergraduates, and over 75% of them were female and/or from underrepresented groups. In addition 16 High School students, 2 post-baccularate alumni, 2 technicians, 4 post-doctoral researchers, and a staff research scientist worked with the MERCURY investigators.

During the 2014-15 academic year, the 17 MERCURY investigators worked with 119 undergraduate students, 16 high school students, four postdoctoral fellows, one staff research scientist, and two technicians during this grant period. Half of the undergraduate researchers were female (60), 21 were Asian Americans (16F), 11 were Hispanic/Latino (4F), 20 were African American/Black (6F), and one was a Pacific Islander (F). Thus 53 students, or 44% were from underrepresented groups. Overall, not double counting females who belong to these underrepresented groups, 86 of the 119 students, or 72%, were female and/or from underrepresented groups.

During the 2013-14 academic year, the 17 MERCURY investigators worked with 98 undergraduate students, eight high school students, five postdoctoral fellows, and two technicians during this grant period. Over 75% of the students were female and/or from underrepresented groups.

During the 2012-13 academic year the 17 MERCURY investigators worked with 90 undergraduate students, six high school students, four postdoctoral fellows, and two technicians during this grant period. Over 75% of the students were female and/or from underrepresented groups.

A major venue for the success of the MERCURY consortium comes through our National Conference, which is open to undergraduates and faculty from every institution.

We organized the MERCURY conference at Bucknell University in 2013, 2014, and 2015. The 2015 conference at the end of July was the 14th annual conference. See http://mercuryconsortium.org/. At the MERCURY conferences undergraduate students and faculty from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) attend the conference and undergraduates (and high school students) present their work in the style of a Sanibel poster session while also learning from six prominent keynote speakers from academia and industry.

In 2013 the undergraduate students presented 51 posters, of which 28 were by women students. In 2014 the students presented 65 posters, 27 by women students. In 2015 the students presented 46 posters, 21 by women students. Students benefit from the opportunity to present their work to experts. Faculty benefit from the networking opportunities. The conferences usually average around 85 in attendance. The 2014 conference had 110 participants and the 2015 conference had 76 participants. Many faculty and students from institutions that are not part of the MERCURY consortium attend the conference and benefit from networking and discussions with other faculty and students working in computational chemistry.
